awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Safer batteries to mitigate injuries from accidental ingestion in children
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to develop a novel battery design which rapidly deactivates in contact with aqueous environments. Every year, tens of thousands of children suffer as a result of ingesting coin cell batteries. These children may needlessly suffer debilitating and sometimes fatal consequences. Exposure to unforeseen battery ingestions increases with the proliferation of Internet of Things (IOT) and wearable devices that use compact, high energy density, batteries replaceable by the consumer. Such batteries are increasingly required to have higher potential or capacity (or both) and pose an ever-greater risk to unsuspecting children. Worldwide, 10 billion coin cell batteries are sold annually and this is one of the fastest growing, highest margin consumer battery segments. These sales are expected to translate to nearly $2 billion in the lithium battery primary market by 2024. Consumer use of coin cells is growing; By 2030, 125 billion IOT devices are expected to be sold globally many powered by coin cells. The magnitude of the  potential child-ingestion problem is significant. 

This SBIR phase I project seeks to reduce children's injuries caused by injesting coin cell batteries by using a novel material design to rapidly deactivate coin cell batteries when they come into contact with aqueous environments. The research addresses the fundamental issue of electrochemical burns. The solution will conform to established standards for coin cell batteries in terms of electrical and other performance requirements. Phase I research efforts will include identifying suitable materials for specific component(s) of a coin cell battery, demonstrating that novel material combinations can be manufactured using scalable process, and producing hand-assembled lithium primary coin cell batteries that have an appropriate open circuit potential and electrical discharge characteristics under continuous ohmic load and pulsed discharge conditions.  The teams also seeks to demonstrate that fully-assembled cells deactivate rapidly when the cells come into contact with aqueous environments. The tests include the use of highly sensitive source measure unit(s) to apply potential and detect current in aqueous environments. Additionally, material robustness will be tested for electrical, mechanical, and processability parameters.  Electrical discharge and battery performance testing procedures will be used in accordance with current standards.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of the grant is to investigate and determine a feasible approach towards a safer battery that mitigate ingestion related injuries in children.

 

Through the work performed during this grant, we were able to demonstrate the feasibility of a safer battery prototype, which is branded by Landsdowne Labs LLC as the ChildLokTM battery.

 

Intellectual Merit

We have invented a novel safer battery that is designed to reduce injuries from accidental ingestion. This battery performs to the required specification of standard CR2032 batteries, when considered from an electrical performance perspective. The battery?s performance remains unchanged under high humidity storage conditions whereas it deactivates under direct contact with water.

This deactivation feature is very important because when a battery exposed to a biologically relevant environment, such as an aqueous salt solution and the model pig esophageal tissue, the cell deactivates rapidly so as to reduce major hazardous reactions due to the battery energy density.

It was also demonstrated the safer battery can be handled normally, subject to wear and tear of the nature encountered under daily use conditions. Our filed patent application for this invention was granted by USPTO.

Broader Impact

Each year that goes by where battery manufacturers do not directly address battery ingestion safety, 4000 new cases of ingestions are reported to the national poison control center. The total number of battery ingestions cases reported only in the US from 1985 to 2019 was 90,517 cases. The Button Battery Task Force (BBTF) surveyed medical professionals and found that ?Survey data from 400+ medical professionals who manage pediatric foreign body ingestions have shown that only 11% of button battery ingestions are actually reported to a data source?. Children often obtain loose or unsecure batteries. Subsequent ingestions usually go unseen, and life-threatening injury can occur in as little as a few hours. By proving that a safer design is technically feasibility, Landsdowne Labs intends to solve this much needed pain point for consumers in offering a safer battery option in the coin battery market place.

By spurring on development and innovation in this market, and showing that it is possible to create a safer battery that reduces the devastating injuries that may be caused to a child upon ingestion, while retaining the technical performance needed to appropriately power portable electronic devices. The broader impact of our work highlights that it is possible to create further developments in the application space intersecting electrical devices and water-based media.

In general, while electrical power and water don?t generally mix together, there are nuanced design possibilities that can be explored in this space, with the work performed for this grant demonstrating a societally relevant solution to an under-reported problem.


Last Modified: 05/18/2023
Modified by: Ravikumar Vasudevan

Image
  • Side by side comparison of a standard control battery (left) vs Landsdowne ChildlokTM safer battery (right) in contact with hydrated deli ham.
    Landsdowne Labs LLC
    Copyrighted
    Ravikumar Vasudevan
    Landsdowne Labs Safer CR2032 Battery
